topics.body:
Here's a random post about games:

For those of you that play minecraft and find that mods are too complicated to understand here's a random tidbit; apparently minecraft 1.8 is programmed so poorly optimization wise that a lot of the people that made crap mods are going "uh. . . uh. . . How the fuck do I do this?"

If you dislike minecraft mods I would wait till 1.9 because what's happening is that 1.8 is massively thinning the herd and the people that are working on 1.8 mods are like professional programmers and that make mods as a hobby.

In the future what minecraft mods are probably going to be more like Botania or such where they are actually good easy to understand and not laggy.

Tl:dr; if you like minecraft, but dislike mods I would suggest trying potentially 1.8 or 1.9 when they come out cause a lot of the poorly optimized mods or the poorly programmed mods or such are just faceplanting hard trying to update to the latest versions of minecraft.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

Tl:dr; tis literally a flesh wound.

topics.body:
"@Gizoid101":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55a70c1a636872245a002e0d#post_55a70c1a636872245a002e0d
"FTB is the best choice":http://www.feed-the-beast.com/

The easiest way is to pick something like ftb lite 3 for the latest version, ftb lite is extremely easy on your computer and doesn't take a supercomputer to run, then when you go into the launcher click "edit mod pack"; then click add mod then just find a jar file with a mod you want to play.

Easiest way, *BUT* every time the mod pack upgrades you would need to re-add the mods you want.  Pain in the ass, but easiest way in the world.
